The important point is that they are used simultaneously. With C++, the main part of the program is usually encoded. You can call it the Kernel. C++ is a compiled language that generates very fast executables. This part of the program is where all calculations are finally executed. With Python, you order the Kernel to do what interests you. Python is an interpreted language that is very slow but where the code it is not necessarily compiled. Here you write simple commands to request to the Kernel what you want to be calculated. The key point is to avoid that any calculation be done with Python, but in the super fast C++ Kernel. C++ can not replace Python nor Python can replace C++, both languages ​​are needed to work together and do what they do best. This symbiosis of the two most powerful languages ​​of today, working in parallel, is doing what is AI. Almost all frameworks of AI today are written this way, using C++ and Python simultaneously. Where should you code? It depends, if you want to modify / extend / improve the Kernel, you must do it with C++. If you only want to use that Kernel to solve a particular problem, you must code in Python. And, please, stop comparing C++ with Python, they are not comparable, they are complementary. They have totally different purposes and objectives. The total power is obtained when you use both languages ​​simultaneously. Regards.
